title: Concepts for Fostering Resilience and Post-Traumatic Growth in Entrepreneurs

messages.content: Review the uploaded documents: 'Bilal Literature Review.pdf', 'Wellbeing and Impact - Wamda Thought Leadership Article Number 1.pdf', 'Wamda Article Idea.pdf', 'Bilal Ghalib Research Project.pdf', and 'Character Strengths And Fostering PTG (draft to publish).pdf'. Extract the key concepts and definitions related to post-traumatic growth, resilience, humor, and entrepreneurship. Summarize these concepts in bullet points, noting any significant overlap or unique ideas in each document.

Literature review of Bilal Ghalib

Final readings list	1
Main concepts/results spotted	1

The master thesis topic: Resilience and Post Traumatic Growth in the Context of Conflict Zone Entrepreneurship.

Research question: What factors supported the development of Character Strengths and PTG for entrepreneurs in Lebanon after the Beirut Blast?

Final readings list
Option A: The reading list is available on airtable:

Research Journal: https://airtable.com/shrPKUDlNifYQyjJV
Papers: https://airtable.com/shrgyPrxWkYrYL5Hj
Authors: https://airtable.com/shrA6sNbyHKcjy20U

Main concepts/results spotted

Snippet from airtable

1/ Context
Bring to the table and describe the object/thing/phenomenon you decide to study.

Entrepreneurship education is a methodology gaining traction in sustainable development as a persistent way to increase employment, reduce inequality, and increase stability. In these countries, the entrepreneurial landscape is non-ideal due to the additional challenges within the political and economic landscape. Potential violence and social unrest entrepreneurs must deal with plus the usual stress and challenges of operating an enterprise. The additional stressors of an entrepreneur working in a conflict-prone area on top of the challenges of capitalising and operating in conditions of uncertainty shine a light on the need to understand emotion, affect, character strengths and resilience alongside more traditional economic and entrepreneurial measures.

The insights gained from the edge cases of entrepreneurship education will bear fruit for educators, policymakers, and multinational NGOs who seek a sustainable development path. Challenges and stressors confront anyone wanting to create change and identifying cross-culturally relevant interventions to nurture resilience and support entrepreneurial orientation, action, and success will be beneficial.

2/ Presentation of references

To clarify the challenges and opportunities presented to governments, universities and other entrepreneurial ecosystem facilitators this review goes over a subset of the literature discussing:
Entrepreneurial Intent (Zhao, Seibert, & Hills, 2005),
Entrepreneurial Orientation and Intent
Entrepreneurial Cognition and Action
And viewing them in relation to:
Self-efficacy (Benight & Bandura, 2004)
Resilience / Post Traumatic Growth
Emotion / Affect - as mood and passions (Baron 2008)
And hope - defined as a cognitive capability in as opposed to an emotion (Arend 2020).

Within this literature review, the following relevant questions were salient in regards to identifying the factors relating to entrepreneurial intent and action in conflicted areas:

What mediates entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
How do conflict and trauma promote or demote the factors leading to entrepreneurial motivation and action?
What interventions enhance the promoting factors and inhibit the demoting factors leading to entrepreneurial motivation and action?

Concepts
Within question 1, we identified the concepts of positive affect (Bernoster et al. - 2020), and metacognition as factors that support entrepreneurial self-efficacy.

Within question 2, we identified the concepts of Post-Traumatic Growth(Shakespeare-Finch 2011), Brooding VS Rumination (Garcia 2014), and Hope (as cognitive capability VS emotion).

Conceptual Map Example: Positive Affect mediates between Self Efficacy and Innovative Behaviors.

Within question 3 we identified the concepts of Signature Strengths training within the Values in Action Character Strengths model (Schutte and Malouff - 2019), Reappraisals and positive reinterpretation (Scheier, Weintraub, & Carver, 1986), Deliberate Rumination, Benefit Finding (Ai et al. 2005), and Social Support.

The surveyed papers demonstrate a lack of specificity between positive affect, life satisfaction, and happiness (Schutte 2019).

Results
It is clear that affect matters. The literature reviewed demonstrates that positive affect mediates the relationship between self-efficacy and the innovative behavior of entrepreneurs. (Mielniczuk 2020) which aligns with (Bandura, 1997)’s explanation of how self-efficacy enhances wellbeing and outcomes.
(Uy et al. 2017) demonstrated that higher Affect Spin (the dynamics of changing mood/feelings) impedes progress on entrepreneurial milestones. The impact remains, regardless of the type of affect Spin - either entirely within the positive range or ranging from positive to negative. Affect stability is related to wellbeing and wellbeing pertaining to goal orientation and goal orientation to supporting venture progress.
What inhibits progress for entrepreneurs in conflict and challenged areas? Across studies, we find that intrusive rumination and brooding stemming from a traumatic event mediate the relationship between subjective and post-traumatic symptoms (García 2015). The monitoring that comes from a metacognitive perspective can be related to intrusive rumination. In (Learning 2015) we see that metacognition is the mediating factor between Social Support and Wellbeing.
The previous results demonstrate the correlates of affect and internal narrative to entrepreneurial behaviors and intention. Metacognition also plays a vital role as a mediator of wellbeing while highlighting a question of the role metacognitive processes have in types of rumination.
Continuing the explanation of trauma, rumination and wellbeing as factors upstream to entrepreneurial outcomes (Triplett, Tedeschi, Cann, Calhoun and Reeve 2012) conducted a path analysis to identify how traumatic experiences lead to increased life satisfaction. They identified the process of Deliberate Rumination (sometimes mediated/triggered by Intrusive Rumination) to be a core factor.

Meaning and story making is a subtext across much of the literature read about trauma and entrepreneurship. It is a concept which underlies rumination in the previously discussed studies. As described in (Janoff-Bulman 1989) - a traumatic event may lead to posttraumatic stress due to a break in our assumptive worlds, the schema we come to expect is no longer relevant. Meaning connects things, and traumatic events and disruption disconnect them (Park 2010). It is becoming clear that one way Deliberate Rumination supports Post-Traumatic Growth and through that can support entrepreneurship in the developing world is through the accompanying resilience of PTG and the reappraisal and the telling of a new story.
The relationship between deliberate and intrusive rumination, affect, and action is becoming a clear exploration area. (Baumeister and Wilson, 1996) identified four needs for meaning: Need for purpose, need for value/justification, the need for efficacy, and finally the need for self-worth. (Bullough et al., 2014) have demonstrated a relationship between entrepreneurial self-efficacy and resilience with Entrepreneurial Intent. The integration of self-efficacy between the needs for meaning and a component supporting entrepreneurial intent demonstrates the complex web of effects that inspire or dim the light on entrepreneurship motivations.
Lastly, Posttraumatic Growth is identified through the development of specific character strengths. (Peterson 2008) demonstrated the development of particular Character Strengths for individuals who have gone through a traumatic experience at some time in their lives. Peterson identified this growth an arbitrarily long time after the traumatic event without conducting an intervention; this is intriguing since it reinforces the theory (Bonanno 2004) proposes - that resilience and Post-traumatic growth are the general response most people undergo posttraumatic experience as a part of the natural healing process. While Bonanno suggests that some interventions (journaling to help with reappraisal) may encourage Post-Traumatic Growth, the research demonstrates many paths to PTG and many people find it independently. An uplifting perspective.

4/ Limits of the existing studies
Measurement challenges:
The majority of the papers in this study used self-reported measures and recommended alternative approaches to assessing factors. (Bernoster et al. - 2020)
Issues with non-longitudinal studies: How to define success? Measuring Self Efficacy and Resilience, as correlates to Entrepreneurial Intent (Bullough 2013), found convincing evidence. However, without measuring entrepreneurial behavior and entrepreneurship impact (jobs created, families sustained, the positive impact of entrepreneurial activities), the demonstration of the correlation between resilience and self-efficacy with entrepreneurial intentions opens the doors to longitudinal studies exploring outcomes of those intentions.

Along with desiring to validate their study across in diverse cultures outside Spain and Portugal, (Mortan 2014) identified that their research is limited by the shortage of empirical evidence on the relationship amongst Entrepreneurial Self-efficacy and how it is related to Emotional Intelligence and Entrepreneurial Intention. (Mortan 2014)

5/ Research question
Some questions emerge after reviewing the literature: How does engaging in an entrepreneurial task impact emotions - how are they reciprocal? Are there positive/negative spirals, and how what starts them, stops them, encourages them? What are the interrelationships between emotion and cognition and entrepreneurial phenomena (Shepherd, 2015)? What is the relationship between metacognition, rumination and entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
All important questions. Due to prior acquisition of Character Strengths Data (pre/post) for people within and without an entrepreneurship program (ACSI) identifying changes and after the Beirut Blast of 2020, there is an opportunity to ask a new question:
What factors supported the development of Character Strengths and PTG for entrepreneurs in Lebanon after the Beirut Blast?
The relevant factors can be determined through qualitative interview referencing some of the concepts referred to in this literature review (rumination, PTG, metacognition, social support, etc.). A theoretical model will be developed to identify the strongest correlations that buffered the individuals within the ACSI program from a 1 point drop in their Character Strengths their peers outside the program experienced. This knowledge will support other entrepreneurial educators in similarly challenging environments to improve their programs and support entrepreneurs working to create a better world. This knowledge will help conflict zone entrepreneurs grow from their challenges, like a phoenix.
6/ Reference

Thesis: Post Traumatic Growth, Character Strengths, Humor, Deliberate Rumination, Social Support and Entrepreneurial Training Programs as Presilience Training - Summary of Ideas
The following interviews were conducted and tagged by Bilal Ghalib, co-founder of Bloom.pm, and Masters Student at the Learning Planet Institute in 2021. Bilal had run an entrepreneurial acceleration program for social impact entrepreneurs in Lebanon which happened to overlap with COVID, the start of the economic collapse and protest movements, as well as an enormous blast called the Beirut Port Explosion that destroyed many homes, buildings, offices, businesses and killed many people. Many of the participants were impacted physically and all impacted mentally. The research used a mixed methods approach focusing on the tool that was used prior to the blast to assess their VIA score (values in action characters profile from the school of positive psychology) it has been shown that the Flourishing measure and higher scores on VIA are correlated, thus we take this measure as a proxy for wellbeing. We also note individual factors like humor, teamwork, leadership and others seem to buffer participants from the negative impacts of the Blast. Our research attempts to identify factors that correlate with post traumatic growth as we witnessed that most of the participants that went through our program returned to their baseline VIA wellbeing proxy faster than those who only attended a two week program where we were able to assess them, and then we asked them to return for an assessment at the same time as when we assessed people that went through both the 2 week program and the 3 month program. We believe we identified something in the 3 month program that we’d like to isolate and theorize the operations of systematically to develop a framework and impleemntation suggestions for other programs, educational and in business, to support the development of “pre-resillience” aka: presilience.

Do you see a role for entrepreneurs in Lebanon given the current situation?
For each crisis, opportunities rise. [[Code: Silver-Linings]]For these crises opportunities can be found by entrepreneurs and work with it. You find a need and there must be solutions to the problems. [[Code: Entrepreneurship-Solution to problems]]
Are entrepreneurs in Lebanon able to work to solve these problems?
A lot of potential brilliant minds, if there's no support it'll be hard to maintain. If not funded, supported by any means that will bring your project to ruin. [[Code: Response-Suggest to fund projects]] Loose hope - that's bad. [[Code: Feeling-Hopeless]]

Family, basically. [[Code: Security]] We still have a secure income. [[Code: Financial]] Which is good. Income is not dependable right now, so... Family/friends. are the main support. In a sense we're already far from the blast itself. So it's good, I think
How do you see personal values / ways you want to be in the world. Values and the conversation?
Values like honesty, courage, perspective. For these you have to be honest with yourself, needs/plans, are you willing to do what it takes to achieve them. You have to have courage to start. Trust me you have to have a lot of courage to start these days.[[Code: Value-Courage]] You have to have a lot of courage to start. some of them will succeed. [[History/Background]][[002 Interview]]
Weekend Plans?
Training for 52 interns. For interns everywhere. Creating content working with JIL and Nawaya/Enjaz. Onboarding interns. Teaching employability skills to help with organization. I'm only at home all the time. Sleep is for the weak. Been saying this for four years. Super happy, my mental health is good, because I'm making a change[[Code: Value -Hope]]. I'm dealing with a 100 people and I'm still happy/satisfied. Always on calls. Making a change in people's lives, empowering little people[[Code: Altruism]]... Even moms. Go to session for 45 mins and I spend 1.5 hours, talking to moms telling them new things about how to deal with education with kids stuck at home for the last two years. THey have no discipiine 0 social skills. Things are changing a lot. We're setting up a training program for educators, an elearning process for our educators because they need psycho social support and advanced educational techniques as well as coding since they need all these things now. [[Code: Vision]]
WonderEd doing amazing. There's a coding activity book for little ones. New coding lesson everyonce in a while. And it's easy, people buy in advance the kit and we send them a book. The whole team is Lebanese and living in Lebanon. All 7 of them. We have partnerships with nursuries. All our current clients are back. A lot of people are engaging with our content on social media.
Interviewer: Is the Business sustainable?
No, it can't be, we make money in Lebanese and spend in Dollars. It's crazy, we can do so much with 5000$. Our entire months spend is 1000$. When I start selling my activity book outside, that will be able to start making revenue. Till we have a marketing plan to sell outside Lebanon we can't be sustainable. I need to translate the book from English to Arabic. The business is ready, it just needs a push to continue forward [[Code: Realistic]]
Do you live with your family?
Yes

What changes did you experience this year?
It's been a life changing year. Mainly a the difference with interacting with people. On pen and paper my BDD job was my first job. and 3 days after the start of my time with BDD the blast happened.Code
What was the blast like?
I still have nightmares, I have PTSD. Do you really want to know what it's like. I had some calls with people from projectName. And suddenly the glass office I was in all collapsed and the couch I was sitting on was full of glass. Allah itlatuf (god intervened with mercy) it was a matter of minutes. I was caught up on my way down to the floor below with my manager having a silly discussion when the blast happened. And the whole lower floor was full of blood, everyone had to be taken to the hospital. We were so scared to move. Because there were two we expected a third. We all thought we were being blasted. Because of this we created a fireman (Ed) who was sewn in response, it was a determination for us that ^&*$# it we're staying. We're doing this for the country despite all the @^&*( we're living through. It was created after the blast as a demonstration that we want to manufacture here, we want to create jobs, we want to build something for the kids that are deprived of toys, their childhood even. [[Code: Feeling-Stuck]][[Code: Altruism]]
Any reminder brought back feelings about it
Any sound/ thunder / cars with big stereos with Music out loud. I'd start to shake.
I had trouble staying asleep
Every morning, I couldn't move out of bed. Survivor guilt. [[Code: Feeling Survivor Guilt]] Wasn't wounded/hurt. Saw people who were hurt(blood on the ground) why did that happen.
Psychological pressure I sleep, yet still have nightmares. Photographic memory. There's no security, the Israeli planes are flying so low/ see them. [[Code: Security]] still today. In Beirut. I live near Hamra. Hearing them every day creates pressure on us. Always afraid. I work on the balcony. It might happen to me first (not inside) [[Code: Feeling-Vigilance]]
When I went to BDD, I started thinking if anything happened no one would think that I was there. BDD the bathrooms have no windows 3 walls/door. If it breaks - we could have a fire, then what to do? I can still see it. [[Code: Feeling-Stuck]]
I felt irritable and angry
Anger is projected into the work. I want to become something despite the $iTTy situation. As Lebanese, despite everything, we will still make it on a regional and global level. We want to make money/ get better. When I talk to the youth. I go 15 EXTRA miles because I have access to them. [[Code: Altruism]]Instead of 15mins we talk for 3 hours. WEF forum - content creation - we need content in Arabic. Teaching them how to make money out of it. From mansouriyyah. If people - no one will help us we must. I feel so angry I get resources and teach them above and beyond to help them become better people	Trying as much as possible. I do fail. Get up every day	 [[Code: Personality Trait]]

[[Concluding Statements]][[002 Interview]]
Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
Who were you able to speak to about your experience?
I’m very open with everyone, with my employees I’m very close to them. Software engineers are like computers, I can talk to them but they don’t talk back. I’m never only talking about myself. I normalize talking about emotions so they’re encouraged to share with me.[[Code: Altruism]] No matter what encounter I want to leave something with each person I meet. That someone might remember this conversation and perhaps think in a new way.
Talking to people is no longer bound to my physical constraints so I’m talking to many more people these days. I have different communities I talk to. I go and round up people to talk to their different communities and find myself talking to a group of 40 people inspiring them. Aye, kthier.
What did the accelerator mean during the blast period?
I still remember, noticing, during the weekly check ins - I was having a rough period in my life in June/July before the blast. I was done with school, I had graduated and there was hyperinflation. I felt I had to get a job to help the family sustain. I was actively looking and feeling panic and we were as a family operating on savings. My dad was telling me that my retirement was less than 10,000 dollars, imagine that. [[Code: Financial]] So it was crazy. I noticed I’m using the word “Frustrated a lot” - Munir mentioned that I was “frustrated a lot” and it stood out to me. I realized that being frustrated is not productive while you’re in a startup because you need to be innovative and creative and being frustrated doesn’t help you come up with new ideas. [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]] I got this thing with berrytech and finally I relaxed. [[Code: Safety]]
1
All the calls were really so helpful. Not everyone was on the calls all the time, we wanted everyone to be there! People have lives and you can’t force people to always join. I’m the kind of person who always comes up with ideas in conversation. I was talking with my designer and had an idea, started sketching and it was an unannounced brainstorming session. [[Code: Social-Support]][[Code: Value-Creativity]]. We sketched almost half of the book. Talking out loud you get more ideas.
You were there for us, and the cash support really helped a lot. The cash support, before leaving my job, the money I received from you had just finished and then I got the job. So September was covered and it was such good timing. My contract ends in June with Berrytech and I am very confident that I will get another opportunity somewhere else. I’ve been doing a lot of good [[Code: Personality Trait]]
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
I strongly believe that entrepreneurs will save the region. We’re non-partisan, non-political, we’re grassroots, we’re in pain and from the pain we’re trying to do good and create products. I’m very proud of all the people working in startups, especially the people empowering people, teaching people how to think, sharing new skills. Everything involving human development is multiplied by 2000% because that’s someone doing something new and it has a ripple effect. When you empower a person you empower many more indirectly. Entities like Nawaya, Enjaz, Dot, who are getting money from outside, empowering people to start coming up with projects and I’m very happy with the sessions they give. I start telling them - I know the situation is hard, you need to make money, dollars, not Lebanese. The country has a lot of raw materials, but our minds are not industrial, when you think about how much goodness is in the country. As simple as flowers, honey, how can we innovate? The plentitude of potatoes in Bekaa? Create a market for you. Make the spoons from honey, it’s very nice. I buy it because we can, companies are making money. WHat can we invent. Create new products from the earth, learn e-commerce, we’re teaching you ecommerce. Learn the tools, it’s for free. As much as I can I’m trying to share this. Don’t make the same product and sell it in the same village. In Beirut no one makes authentic “mooneh” - we look for the people who do? There’s lots of people like me and expats who’re looking for Lebanese products, the smell of the region. [[Code: Expat-support]] The entities are teaching the skills they need to transform the resources around them into products. And this is how we will emerge from our problem, it’s industrialization and creating products. [[Code: Vision]]
1
What do you say the people leaving?
I won't lie, sometimes I feel like leaving too. Why do I think about it? To keep this engine/enthusiasm/giving to people I have to feel secure[[Code: Feeling-Fear]]. Not that I will die at any instant. So much is online so I can do so much of my work online. I can be effective even if I’m not physically in the country. I think of my safety, my family… and my earnings. Now I’m fine. After a while will I still be fine? I’m investing from my income, will I still be able to invest in my team? That’s the one thing I’m thinking about. [[Code: Feeling-secure]] [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]] I’m investing in the base, raising this “child” so that one day the company will come and pay me back and take care of me when I’m older. Thank goodness God has given me a salary. I see tangible results. We’re going to print the book and sell it and make money from it. I can see it all. [[Code: Vision]] It’s not like we’re playing and not doing anything.

Why are you focusing on vlogging now?
When I went to college I was studying architecture, I realized it wasn’t what I want. My mom got a brain tumor and I’d already lost my father when I was a kid, so this is my mom and I might lose her. I felt really threatened I might need to take a decision that would change my life. But I changed my majors from architecture to fine arts. I never thought of it before because society[[Code: Negative-Peer-Pressure]] told me I could never make a living from fine arts, that’s B#$l $44  I changed majors and didn’t tell anyone. I thought my mom would go into another attack, she didn’t.
They were telling me you’re running away from duties that’s why you shifted majors. I told them, “If I graduate and ask you for money, don’t give it to me”. [[Code: Self-Determination]] I founded my business a year before I graduated, Teeba. I was working on digital content and marketing before I graduated. Now I have 2 years of experience working in an agency, as a freelancer, with NGOs and with Teeba. [[Code: Feeling-Pride]]
I bring my art and genuinity to my Teeba products. Each product is it’s own work of art.
I am always willing to learn more. I can never get enough of what I know. With how I felt with work, and running my business, and and and… What made most the sense is the lifestyle that affects me, it helped me feel like I’m thriving. Going for this decision I’ll have more time for my art, (keep one job). You need to get experience being a team member before you can be a team leader. I’m at the stage where I’m founding my team and learning to be a leader.

How have you been coping after the blast?
What were you doing in the aftermath of the blast?
Rehabilitating grocery shops and small businesses training them stocking the shops. Were working for 6 months as a volunteer. Being on the streets with the people, gives me a feeling that I made something. When I tell my kids I was there in the blast, I can tell them we helped people and that's what you should do. I was also helping in repainting kids rooms. [[Code: Volunteering]]
Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it.
I don't perceive things bad/right. I don't overreact to things. I take things neutrally. I take some time to assess the feeling / incident I am in. It will take a few mins. I recall often that I tell people that I will get back to them after 5-10 mins. I ask "What do you mean about it" I don't open much room for misunderstanding. In what sense did you mean that? Not an easily provoked person. [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]
Where did you develop this skill?
Arts taught me a lot. Being objective. I lived in this culture taboos - I always share this example. We used to draw nudes. We were very objective about it regardless of what it has inside it. Definitely connected with meditation [[Code: Coping-Meditation]], I deal with people the same way I deal with my thoughts. Zen books, mindfulness books and would read 15/16. Just jumping into technology and school. I had an iPod touch we did a lot of things on it. I always searched for ways to calm my mind. I had struggles when I was a kid. Didn't have a perfect childhood (no childhood actually). Searched for things that can help calm my mind. my brother was abroad and asked for xyz book and he brought them with him. [[Code: Experience-Prior-Violence]] Developed meditation with time - took me 4 years (till 20) till i can fall deeply into a meditative state. 15 year old, no support. 12-15 black hole from this time. When I finally got out of depression, I immediately became a semi mature person for 15 years old. I just started therepy 1 month ago. I believe there are still things in childhood I need to discover and I need the support of someone else. I don't tell people about it, it's still a taboo to talk about it. I get the guidance that I need. If I don't invest in myself there's nothing more worthy. When I was financially strong enough to invest in myself it was the most important thing I could do. With being a human we have a lot of complexity. And when I see that I'm questioning purpose I know I need some help. [[Code: Value-Self-care]]  [[Code: Therapy]] [[Code: Coping]]

No matter if you're motivated or not, see the end of the tunnel or not. If you're self disciplined and consistent will hold you till you get to the breakthrough.
How are things for you this week?
I flooded myself with work. Being in my bubble and doing good things. Being productive, being able to contribute to projects. Self fulfilling. I can waste as much time as I want. I'd rather invest it even if it's with other people and other companies. I don't mind that.[[Code: Value-Self knowledge]] Eventually things will work out. I have lots of projects that I've been approached with many. projects I'm jumping two feet in - especially entrepreneurship and helping startups get their things right and get their products. I wasn't fooled. General knowledge of things isn't always the best way to do it. Ecommerce - very efficient. Taking a lot of projects, consulting with ITC people, women led businesses. Their own ecommerce. Last week she told me she was paying 1500 a month and getting no conversions
Do you live with your family?
Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
I tried for two full years of a career as an employee. To tell you the truth, there are pros and cons. I think that I had a lot of success in my company. I made the brave decision to kill it. I spent a lot of time and emotions in it. And at this time it harms me more than it gives. [[Code: Reprioritization]]

[[Concluding Statements]][[008 Interview]]
Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
The experienced ones have a duty to cultivate young entrepreneurs.[[Code: Altruism]] At 35 I can still have a good amount of energy. Younger ones that are 20-23 - fresh out of UNI that have literally no idea what's happening outside. They either get stuck in a job that they don't like. Get suicidal thoughts or want to leave. Entrepreneur to be able to start a company to have employees to grow economically has to have discipline / Faith. The ones that have experience would rather go to another country. If you want to keep the brain drain.... to keep them here you have to advise/lead/to give the best of your knowledge to help them create something that is sustainable. It's not easy. Huge skillset, highly employable. For a fresh grad. They need people to genuinely want them to stay in the country. to help them be sustainable, create a job/ a business. A moral duty. Believe it or not. I advise more than 30 startups, all of them are young kids. I do this out of purpose. It gives me fulfillment to be honest with you. [[Code: Altruism]]I didn't make it at their age. They need incentives, cash in their hands. They shouldn't be worried about their livelihood - bread for their family at the end of the day, Less damaging. I'm here because my parents are old, I'm the one they rely on.[[Code: Family-Responsibility]] Even if it's on my own expenses and the life i'm longing to have with my future wife. I have my French tech visa, but I'm here. I'm here until things get better. I had people who I really appreciate who were pushing. Mentors, people I respect. Business people mostly. Mentoring/entrepreneurs. helped push you to get out of the grey zone. I was looking for an opportunity. Someone told me. Radical, straight to the point answers give you good material to reflect on. easier to take decisions

Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?

2017 was a strange year, I wanted to work on my own projects. The "Real Deal" - ohhhh, where will it go. It was the year where nothing/everything really happened. I had a fight with my parents, left he house in an anger fit. It was an explosion of all the trauma that I lived as a child and I realized I didn't want to be a in that bubble anymore. And I was very keen I didn't want to work for someone else anymore. At that point in my life I felt I was working with the devil. All the people that I worked for were people trying to make more money unethically while I was living my worst days while they were supposed to be my best days. soooo - It was a moment where I realized. khalas. I can't find a way to put words on it. I've been recently thinking about how I got here (which is no where really) what are the events and what's the story. I have a hard time putting words on it. It's a part of my recovery and processing.

[[Concluding Statements]] [[014 Interview]]
Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
Got some opportunities in different trainings. ACSI, all the mentorship/exposure network. Hearing experiences from different people. Everyone has something to add for you. If someone shares something I will think about it, researcher mindset, I will reflect on it to see if I can use it. The SheInstitute, a Swedish program for women it was very insightful. All the things she's learned. Attending all the different training online. A Masters program, new course, new skills, new ideas. Meeting people online. As well as we had to adapt to being online and having to shift everything online. New ways and shifting new ways adding new skills and professional skills. [[Code: Competence]] [[Code: Empowerment-Through-Learning]] Doing things online needs specific types of things. Personal growth - sticking more to my faith/religion. Helped a lot [[Code: Spirituality]] [[Code: Religious-Prioritization]]
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
Rebuilding Lebanon. [[Code: Feeling-Hopeful]]
Do you believe entrepreneurs can rebuild Lebanon?
Yes. I believe we will always find a way. [[Code: Value-Hope]] It's not something new in Lebanon. People don't stop. Many have traveled and left Lebanon. Every situation furas and ma2asee have furas. People here are creative. If you look at the Syrians and what they're doing in the different countries of the world wherever they are, they are creative. In spite of the 70 million things in us we have creativity. And we try to adapt . Trying to go online, finding new ways/opportunities. It's the time for entrepreneurs. If we don't have entrepreneurs, new ideas, creativity, will help find solutions to the problems we find in the country right now. Because the government in Lebanon doesn't have or do anything. Solutions and garbage. Entrepreneurs do/think about it. so many things I want to do, I would organize myself in time slots and put everything in their own place and start something for my own and just keep going for it. - organize myself, even if it will be a total loss, it's something I will have to start.
How have you been coping after the blast?
First of all "time heals everything" [[Code: Adaptation]] so everyone got a little bit back to "normal" after some time. what do you think about that what the media is doing?

[[History/Background]] [[018 Interview]]
Weekend Plans?
Iftar with my friends. Iftar - planning to go hiking. Didn't work. Weekend before is to go hiking. More of seeing friends / seeing nature when it works.
Easy to make time for nature?
There are weekends where I didn't feel they are weekends. If it's possible if I don't have tight deadlines. It becomes easy to unplug myself. If there are deadlines...
Last weekend - was good. I had a break, this weekend it might be hard because we have a pilot. We want to prepare for it. I like to have fast projects happening because there are a lot of interested people which is good. I see the company growing and it's' good. So it's not always negative to do that (work on the weekend).
Pilot with DOT. Teach students digital skills. They used to teach them, lots of organizations brought people to center and they - it's an opportunity for them to scale. If they can do it in a remote environment they might be able to handle 2x or 3x people to take advantage of the situation online. Used to do 30 students and now they want to do 100 students. I see the future more around blended learning.
Any time to relax on the weekend.
DOT - telegram group - we are trying to engage people in a group. Under research. To work with underserved communities. These people are left behind. The most impact can be. [[Code: Positive-Impact]]
Do you live with your family?
Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
First it started, as I remember. In grade. I wasn't sure how old I was - I started spending more time in the physics lab trying to understand how things work. I started exploring more of electronics and in grade 9 there was a competition to create a sort of project. A technology/innovation - I did something like a smart home. A lot of students do it. I wasn't aware of arduino, how to technically do that by taking an RC car/keyboard. Num lock light, sensor to trigger events from a program. This is how it started first.
At university I started the robotics club. At UNI - my roommate used to order stuff from AliExpress, if people would need any supplies they'd come to our dorm room(more like a maker space). After a while we thought more people in the university students that might be interested, we saw people come to our dorm room with interest so we thought we could start a club where we could build stuff together. We had to find 12 members and we gathered friends. Until now it's still running. It might be the first "Startup" I started
Stround	I used to do freelance development projects. A two person company - not "real UIUX" we were young, started from there. And after that for the final year project we applied for the SPEED Accelerator to fund (ProjectName)
I worked at Anghamy and Toters while in University. I was one of the first four developers. I was the IOs developer.I had some shares in Toters. But then when I went to (ProjectName) I returned everything back to focus on (ProjectName). I don't think my future is in a food app. I'm interested in building things and it's not my passion to work in food. So I took (ProjectName) to the SPEED accelerator. Through the robotics club we started teaching students robotics. Realized it could be done in a more interesting way. They were using the breadboard. The arduino is smart, the raspberry pi is smart, why isn't the breadboard smart? It's a valid and a very simple. Why doesn't it connect to your laptop... it's something we started on for our Final Year project, this is what we applied for in speed. These are the pins of the breadboard
Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?
Can you tell me about how you got into Education.
To go back to school... I knew the education system is not good. I realized that schools didn't take into consideration what we are interested in, if I'm interested in this I'm going to spend time in this. And when I discovered this stuff my grades started getting lower but on the otherside I found something that was interesting for me. As we went through the acceleration program in SPEED, we were able to identify that this idea is not very doable. It needs a lot of... we have limitations on component sizes, we're using SMD/four layers/SMD sensors and everything, there's a limit to that. We're not able to do something something similar to the breadboard. The pin configurations will be different from that... so we zoomed out and thought, why are we doing this, to help students learn electronics - and what if the students were interested in different things? Also schools don't give them options to see / be exposed to new thing. how can we connect them to new learning opportunities that would be interesting for students. So we tried to alter the content to be more interesting for the students. We started zooming out step by step. We were trying to sell courses on ProjectName. We had a major problem. After ProjectName, our customers told us that they don't even have the ability to teach arabic/english how can you expect them to care about learning new things. There are a lot of marginalized people who aren't able to take advantage of online learning and there's a huge opportunity here
Working at Toters/Anghami what did you learn that might be helpful for your entrepreneurial journey.
Ay Anghami I was in touch with Eli Habib, the highest person/co-founder at the company. The work culture there I loved. The thing I learned is that a company doesn't have to be as boring as you think. Even if you are working you can even have fun/have friends. [[Code: Fun-at-work]] Anghami showed me the work culture, it surprised me; how can work culture be that fun. 2, when it comes to connection - the smallest person in the company can be connected to the co-founder - less hierarchy so it was interesting. At Toters, the founder was very focused on the numbers coming from a very big consulting firm. He was very precise and I liked that about him. Even if he spends the night at the office he had a very clear plan and was able to raise the amount he wanted to raise from investors and having a plan and following it strictly.

Bachelors in computer engineering

Then we created the group, we talked to my family/friends outside of lebanon, lots of people donated money. Lots of friends active in Beirut, one of the first things we did we started cleaning up. If I was there, definitely all the time. I don't want to underestimate what other people are feeling by saying all the time myself...

I let myself feel everything. "did you have anything to help with those feelings" - not religious practices, spending time alone. [[Code: Coping-Meditation]] Reflecting, planning, breathing properly. Reminding myself to be here in the present moment, not get lost in the past in the future. It's what I usually do, whatever the case was.

It's not like lebanon hasn't ha things like this before. -it's no 9-11. "We only live once", we live by that. I wasn't here in 14 azar, I was here in aseer - I was in Saida surrounded by troops. Going through that and the explosion now. [[Code: Experience-Prior-Violence]] And the chaos in Lebanon, you expect the worst. [[Code: Feeling-Vigilance]] It's real. It's very expected that Lebanon would go through something like that. This is what the people in power want. If they wanted something good for the country, they'd put their Ego aside and do it. [[Code: Feeling-Anger Corruption]] Everything in this country is flawed.
It's the country I'd choose over any other country. [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]] I'd choose this country over any other country. [[History/Background]] [[020 Interview]]
Weekend Plans?
I spent time with people that I love and spent time with my family. Went to Minia. There really doesn’t feel like there’s a lock down here even. My motto for the weekend is to rest up and get ready to kick the ^*&$( of the week. (laughs)
Week plans?
Lots going on, work work work. Two big projects we’re going to work on, more focus on the learning land program. We got a project with CLS - Center of Lebanese Studies. We’re now expanding our project to all 9 districts. We’re also working on a digital teachers program. We wanted to connect people physically, and we tried as much as possible to keep the personal connection, that’s something that people really need. We went 100% online. So far it’s going well.
Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
My family, everyone has their own business, for sure, and they're all quite traditional. Although, when I was in school I had many experiences with ENJAZ Lebanon [[Code: Experience-Prior-Entrepreneurial-Training]] they joined a lot of classrooms when I was in school during grade 7, 9, 11.  I wanted to become an entrepreneur because the whole system is passive and "I want a job" - "I want to be an engineer". I don't want to be anyone else, I want to be to run my own thing that I'm completely passionate about that I purposely want to pursue and not just go with the flow.
Where does this entrepreneurial drive come from? What differentiated you from your classmates?
There are many factors. I think that I'm more self aware and that brings a lot of power to your hand and head. I think I lived through different experiences to help me reach where I am and I'm looking for more experiences to help me understand [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]"who is [participants name referenced I worked with different non-profits that helped me, and I went to them for help because yeah, I want to be an entrepreneur although I don't have the full set of skills that I need. I worked with a different number of them. One of the things that made me more passionate for education was a program with Teach For Lebanon, it's a program a part of a global program called Teach for All.  You go and work in an underprivileged school and you learn about how the kids are suffering and you learn about so many eye opening things. [[Code: Feeling-Compassion]] [ And the whole experience gives you the feeling, if you have an entrepreneurial mindset, you need to solve all of these problems.[[Code: Altruism]] [[Code: Value-Agency]] [[Code: Feeling-Confidence]]You can't ignore it. Actually a few of the people from the fellowship have become entrepreneurs. We were only like 2-3. I tried to talk to the CEO to talk to more civil society people to train the fellows  who are in the classrooms in entrepreneurship so they can continue. It's just two years in the fellowship. [[Code: Volunteering]] [[Code: Entrepreneurship-Solution to problems]]
What experiences helped you with self awareness?
Being open to learning as much as you can. Whatever workshop, anything, jump in anything. And then know your niche and start to specialize.
Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?

I like this question, it always starts informally. you start thinking about doing things, then you talk to people bring people together and one of the things I'm thinking about now is I really want to solve a problem in education and other people want to solve it and I think about it more. It's a bit critical, it's related to LGBTQ kids in school and no one wants to talk about it. So I catch friends, a psychologist, an activist, and we start this dialog. Sometimes we reach somewhere and sometimes we don't. It's important to have these discussions outside of work places sometimes that builds these spaces. The Journey Towards Entrepreneurial Wellbeing and Impact
by Bilal @ Bloom.pm • Sept 22, 2023
Introduction: Rethinking Trauma and Resilience
2020 is a difficult year to forget. It was the year COVID highlighted the importance of mental health globally, the year of the Beirut Blast, and when we felt the rumblings of global financial destabilization. Entrepreneurs find and exploit risk, but what happens when risk-taking is compounded by a world in flux? What lessons are we learning from the last few years, and how can entrepreneurs and ecosystems adapt? Join me in this series of posts to explore answers to these questions, bridging wellbeing and impact.
Let's begin by delving into how this evolving landscape has impacted my work and perspectives, beginning with a project focused on character strengths.
From Character Strengths to Crisis Response
In July 2020, through my non-profit Bloom.pm I was operating a virtual accelerator for youth in Lebanon, supporting education-focused social enterprises with support from the Asfari Foundation. As a graduate student at the University of Paris - Learning Planet Institute, I researched Character Strengths,first described by Positive Psychology researchers Christopher Peterson and Martin Seligman. I was hoping to find out how these factors related to leading a flourishing life and might be connected to entrepreneurial success.
Then, on August 4, 2020, everything changed. When the Beirut Port Explosion rocked the city, it forced me to think about mental health and wellbeing in a new way.
This sudden shift in focus wasn't unique to us; studies conducted in the region revealed that entrepreneurs at large were grappling with similar challenges.
Building Resilience: Lessons from Lebanon and Beyond
The tragedy had a profound impact, upending lives and altering the course of many entrepreneurial journeys. Faced with a combination of crises—the Beirut blast, the COVID-19 pandemic, political revolution, and economic collapse—many who had once been committed to building their future in Lebanon felt compelled to seek stability and security elsewhere.
The Konrad Adenaur Stftung researched why people were leaving their businesses and moving out of Lebanon. They found that between large and small businesses, 38% can’t cope with the stress of everyday life and are prioritizing their mental health. Over 65% are leaving for quality of life and safety abroad.

Konrad Adenaur Stftung Foundation - Braving the Storm, Safeguarding tThe Lebanese Economy Page 20
Research in Action - Leaving The “Lab”
Through the active research I was conducting with my teams, I found that my work on wellbeing and flourishing wasn’t an “extra”, it was in fact supporting their entrepreneurial efforts. At Bloom, we started hosting sharing circles, online breathwork courses, art therapy, chi gong, and workout classes for entrepreneurs in our programs. We started asking entrepreneurs how they were feeling and began to support each other in a new and deeper way. The data was adding up - the entrepreneurs who were taking action towards their holistic wellness in the face of difficulties were the ones who persisted with their businesses and were happier too!
Since the Arab Spring, I’ve been working on building the entrepreneurial capacity of the MENA entrepreneurship ecosystem. Starting with technical skills through my work on maker/hackerspaces and today through my work with Bloom and our personal/professional growth accelerators. As ecosystem builders, we must address entrepreneurs' need - perhaps more than others - for wellbeing support. And we're not alone in recognizing the significance of this issue; recent research has brought the mental health crisis among MENA entrepreneurs into sharp focus.
Recent studies make this clear, including 2021 research by Wamda, Microsoft for Startups, EMPWR, and H.A.D Consultants, which sheds light specifically on the mental health challenges facing entrepreneurs in the MENA region. That research exposed that, along with economic uncertainty and social upheaval, almost 36% of founders described their mental health as 'bad.' Additionally, while 44.2% spend at least two hours a week decompressing, less than 10% feel their mental state is in a good place. The survey drew heavily from the region's wealthier, more stable nations, with over 50% of respondents from the UAE alone. KSA and Jordan together comprised another 22%. Perspectives from less prosperous MENA countries were limited in the dataset.
Take Action: Join The Wellbeing Survey and Learning Conference
Let’s build a healthier, more impactful ecosystem together! I invite you to join our action-oriented research by taking the Wellbeing at Work Survey.
With your input, we can begin to “diagnose” where our ecosystem is struggling with wellbeing so that we can find the medicine we need. What might we do to help our organizations, governments, and companies bring more wellness to individuals, teams, organizations, and communities?
We are hosting an in-person Wellbeing for Impact Learning Conference in Lebanon on Sept 29. We’d love to see you there to discover the survey's preliminary results, and experience workshops and sessions highlighted by a growing body of research demonstrating that taking care of ourselves is good for business.




















































In 2021, Wamda, in collaboration with Microsoft for Startups, EMPWR and H.A.D Consultants conducted a study assessing the impact of COVID on the entrepreneurship ecosystem mainly in the UAE. They found that the MENA region is a hotspot for multiple challenges, including economic downturns and political unrest. Amidst this, research by psychologists Richard Tedeschi and Lawrence Calhoun shows that it's possible for both individuals and organizations to experience post-traumatic growth. At Bloom, we're focused on leveraging this potential to create resilient ecosystems.
Suggested addition: I'm one of the co-founders of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that operates out of Lebanon regionally through its virtual entrepreneurship programs. In the last years, since the economic collapse, the revolution and protests, the Beirut blast and the devaluation of the currency, we have seen many people leaving Lebanon to find their fortunes elsewhere. What I wonder is: do they have to?



Cultivating Growth with Bloom: A Hands-On Approach
Suggested addition: Many organizations and businesses and governments would prefer to continue to operate in Lebanon, in Morocco, in Tunis, in all of these places. And especially for me, importantly, I am originally from Iraq, and my parents wanted me to grow up in Iraq, but they couldn't because of the wars. And so ever since I was young, I always wondered, is it possible to build in these regions? Some research by ArabNet and the Conrad Stiftung Foundation has indicated that many people have left Lebanon and left their businesses, and a big reason is they're unable to cope with the stress of everyday life and prioritize their mental health. They're also moving abroad in search of quality of life and safety and security. All of these things are big components of well-being and decent work.

Join the Movement: Participate in Our Well-being at Work Survey
At Bloom we are working on a Wwellbeing at Wwork Ssurvey to help us understand the wellbeing gaps in the entrepreneurship ecosystem in the Middle East and to then support the training organizations with resources and tools to help their teams address those needs. Imagine someone aspiring to cross a river.
Imagine you’re trying to swim across a river and you don’t know how to swim. You can either jump and start splashing…. Or you can get a better perspective, understand the terrain, learn to swim and then flow. This metaphor embodies our approach at Bloom, nurturing environments where individuals and organizations can navigate the challenges of our times with grace and efficacy.

Your participation will help shape strategies and interventions that foster post-traumatic growth in our workplaces, creating environments where individuals, businesses, and communities flourish synergistically.

Conclusion: Building a Future Where People and Planet Thrive
As we forge ahead in these tumultuous times, the experiences from regions like Lebanon serve as reminders: mental health difficulties are an inevitable facet of our journey, especially for entrepreneurs.




Recently, the MENA region has served as a crucible, demonstrating the raw and often untapped potential of post-traumatic growth. This concept, illuminated by researchers Richard Tedeschi, PhD, and Lawrence Calhoun, PhD, revolutionizes our understanding of resilience, emphasizing that true growth often blossoms from the ashes of trauma. At Bloom, we are embarking on a mission to facilitate this growth, fostering environments where individuals and organizations don't just bounce back but leap forward, fully equipped to navigate the intricacies of an ever-changing world.
The Expatodus: Unravelling the Underlying Triggers
Before we forge ahead, it is vital to understand the depth of the existing crisis in areas like Lebanon, where a significant fraction of the workforce seeks refuge and opportunities abroad. Recent data uncovers alarming trends:
About 66% prioritize moving abroad for a better quality of life
Around 68% are seeking security and safety overseas
55% are drawn by superior financial opportunities abroad
38% find it imperative to prioritize their mental health, unable to cope with daily stresses in the region
Understanding these nuances is critical as we devise strategies to foster post-traumatic growth, creating ecosystems that retain talent and nurture it to its fullest potential.
Beyond Resilience: The Path of Post-Traumatic Growth
George Bonanno's seminal research on resilience reveals a profound insight: resilience is commonplace. A minority navigate the pathways of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), but a golden segment experiences post-traumatic growth. This growth signifies an elevation, a flourishing that comes with having navigated the complexity of trauma.
Bonanno advocates for identifying and bolstering the factors that propel individuals towards this growth trajectory, moving beyond theoretical constructs to practical, real-world applications. This approach aims to foster what is often termed as "antifragility", presenting a tangible pathway to thriving amidst adversity.
Original Audio:
In 2020, I was running an entrepreneurship training program for social enterprises in Lebanon working in education with support from the Asfari Foundation. I was taking the Entrepreneurship Character Strengths Assessment from the School of Positive Psychology, the Values in Action Characters profile, to see if I could figure out the correlates for entrepreneurship in character traits to understand which ways of being led to persistent and successful entrepreneurs. Yet in the middle of this experiment, in the middle of this training, there was the Beirut terrible explosion that destroyed much of the city and shattered the dreams of many of the entrepreneurs in my program. While initially my research was attempting to identify the qualities, the ways of being that bring us to life, that bring us a sense of fulfillment and flourishing, and support us as well in creating healthy entrepreneurial projects, I suddenly found myself also confronted with the reality of trauma. And I thought that it would be potentially of service to the entrepreneurs in my program, the entrepreneurs that I work with in Lebanon and Iraq and the Middle East and North Africa and in all the places in the world that are experiencing great change and also sometimes trauma as we just saw in Morocco and in Libya. And as we know, none of us are exempt and in our fast changing futures, who knows when we will be confronted with difficulty. So the question came, is it possible to identify the qualities that support people growing through the difficulty? And it turns out that in the scientific literature, there is a factor less known than post-traumatic stress disorder called post-traumatic growth. And I began exploring the factors that relate to post-traumatic growth and how to bring them into the entrepreneurship programs I'm working on.


And so after that experience and understanding that there are factors that are correlated with growth after a trauma, in today's trauma-informed culture it seems like every day there's a news article talking about resilience, trauma, and the importance of having a trauma-informed environment. The fact is most people are actually resilient. It is the norm. If you check out Bonanno's work you will see that resilience is what happens in the middle of the bell curve. There is a small minority that wind up having difficulties and that's what we call post-traumatic stress disorder, people that have long-term negative repercussions, and then there are another small minority that have long-term positive growth outcomes from the experience of difficulty. My question was can we begin to identify those factors and then can we create environments in our entrepreneurship ecosystem, in the entrepreneurial training programs, in our workplaces, in our organizations, in our schools to help us prepare for when the inevitable is bound to happen. We in the past had different support networks around us. As someone who currently works from home and lives far from family and from my dearest friends, I know that my work environment is a big part of my social and and emotional stability. How can we create workplaces that both promote goodness for the individual while simultaneously creating positive business outcomes and especially for social entrepreneurs positive environmental and social impact without burning out the people in our organizations? The research is clear. The data is coming back over and over and over again from the Gallup polls about disengaged workers costing trillions of dollars to the global economy that the time is now to take care of ourselves so that we can take care of our businesses and communities and create the change that we want to see in the world.

I'm one of the co-founders of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that operates out of Lebanon regionally through its virtual entrepreneurship programs. And we have seen in the last years, since the economic collapse, since the revolution and protests, since the Beirut blast, since the devaluation of the currency, many people leaving Lebanon to find their fortunes elsewhere. The question is, do they have to? Many organizations and businesses and governments would prefer to continue to operate in Lebanon, in Morocco, in Tunis, in all of these places. And especially for me, importantly, I am originally from Iraq, and my parents wanted me to grow up in Iraq, but they couldn't because of the wars. And so ever since I was young, I always wondered, is it possible to build in these regions? They're also moving abroad in search of quality of life and safety and security. All of these things are big components of well-being and decent work. This is why we are conducting a well-being at work survey, where we would like to identify what it's like in the ecosystem today. What might we be able to do to help our organizations, our governments, and us as individuals within our companies to bring more wellness to us individually, to our teams, to our organizations, and to our communities? Some things we cannot change: we cannot prevent a tsunami or a natural disaster. But we can change how we talk to each other about it. In my research, it shows that that is actually a bigger determinant of whether or not the difficulties help us grow or collapse.


So back in 2020, immediately after the blast, I was unable to pull myself away from my computer, trying my best to coordinate rescue efforts, data collection, supporting non-stop, until my friend took my laptop away from me, took my phone away from me, and forced me to take a break. It wasn't until then that I realized that I had been overstressing, that I hadn't been sleeping or eating, and that I had been increasingly more effective, more and more ineffective, and less effective over time. And that there's a difference between exerting energy and making progress. Sometimes I like to give the example of someone in the water who doesn't know how to swim splashing and making a mess, versus someone who has taken lessons and uses far less energy but is making it to the other side of the shore. And that is what I would like to bring to our entrepreneurship ecosystem. With this survey, identifying how to bring positive change, starting with the individual, moving to the relational, and then out into the organizational. How can we bring practices that will help us enhance the strength and resiliency of our ecosystem and increase the likelihood that when something happens, we'll be prepared?
In my research on post-traumatic growth and the factors, I found that two really important factors are:
First, people have a strong social network. That means that our offices cannot be places where we don't trust our colleagues, where we are having back-office gossip, where we don't understand the intentions of our leadership. We need to create an environment of deep and meaningful relationships at work. This will be the first place that will create a buffer between whatever is happening and how we feel about it.
Secondly, learning internal conversational skills called deliberate rumination. Intrusive rumination is complaining about what is happening and saying, why is this happening to me? Deliberate rumination is asking, accepting what is happening, what can I do about this situation? And talking to each other about it.






Entrepreneurship Amidst Adversity

In 2020, I led a training program for people starting businesses in Lebanon. We focused on education and got help from the Asfari Foundation. I took a test from the School of Positive Psychology to learn about character traits that make good entrepreneurs.

But then, there was a big explosion in Beirut. It hurt the city and many people's dreams. My work changed because now we also had to deal with trauma.

I wondered if there were qualities that could help people grow through hard times. I found out about something called post-traumatic growth, which is not as well-known as post-traumatic stress disorder.

Now, my goal is to explore how these factors can be part of our entrepreneurship programs around the world where challenges are faced by everyone at some point or another during their journey towards success..

Resilience in Work and Life

After learning that some people grow after going through hard times, we often hear about the importance of being strong in tough situations. Most people are actually good at handling problems. Only a few have long-lasting troubles and others become better because of them.

Can we find out what helps us handle difficulties? And can we make our schools, workplaces, and other places ready for when bad things happen? In the past, we had more support from family and friends around us. But now many of us work far away from them or even from home.

How do we make workplaces that help each person while also helping the business succeed? This is important for businesses that want to create a positive impact on society without making their workers feel too tired or stressed.

The research shows it's time to take care of ourselves so that we can take care of our businesses and communities. By doing this, we can create the change that will make the world a better place.

Bloom.pm: Rebuilding Businesses Locally

I am a co-founder of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that helps people start businesses in Lebanon and nearby areas. In recent years, many people have left Lebanon because of problems like the economy, protests, and the Beirut blast. They are looking for a better life somewhere else.

But do they really need to leave? Many groups want to keep working in places like Lebanon, Morocco, and Tunis. I come from Iraq myself but had to move away when I was young because of wars. Since then, I've wondered if it's possible to build something good in these regions.

Research shows that many people leave their homes and businesses due to stress and not feeling safe or happy where they live. That is why we started a survey about well-being at work. We want to learn what it's like for people today so we can help make things better for everyone.

We know we can't stop big events like natural disasters from happening. But how we talk about them with each other can make us stronger instead of tearing us apart

Efficiency Through Balanced Work-Life

In 2020, after a big event, I couldn't stop working on my computer. My friend made me take a break. That's when I learned that working too much can make you less effective.

Think about someone who doesn't know how to swim but uses lots of energy splashing around versus someone who swims well and gets to the other side easily. This is what we want for our business world.

With this survey, we want to find out how to improve things by starting with ourselves, then our relationships, and finally in our organization. We need strong social networks at work where people trust each other and avoid gossiping or misunderstanding their leaders' intentions.

We also need good thinking skills called deliberate rumination instead of just complaining about problems (intrusive rumination). Deliberate rumination means accepting what's happening and asking what can be done about it while talking with others.

Character Strengths and
Fostering Post-Traumatic Growth
A Research Report Developed During The First Edition Of The Asfari Challenge For Social Innovation




2020 brought many challenges to the already challenging field of Social Entrepreneurship, especially in Lebanon, with the global pandemic, on top of local challenges of the economic collapse, political instability, shortages of foods and medicines, unemployment, and the August 2020 explosion at the port of Beirut.
In our programs and for impact monitoring, we use the Values in Action Character profile (VIA), which offers perspectives on aspects of being that make life worthwhile and supports us in finding ways to help bring out people’s strengths in pursuit of their social entrepreneurial aims.
Our research found that well-being and life satisfaction correlate with self-efficacy and productivity. The more teams feel resourced to face the challenges of life and work, even in chaotic times, the better the outcomes for the teams and their social initiatives.
Bloom's research team conducted qualitative and quantitative research to contextualize the changes seen within the Character Strengths of our participants. Reviewing the data in the context of the challenges that people in Lebanon have faced over the last year, we raised the question: How may our programs impact the people who were part of our programs?
We are interviewing participants who went through the complete 6-month (planned initially as four months) Accelerator Program (May to October 2020) and those who only went through the two-week Sprint Program (in April 2020) to deepen the understanding of how people respond to and grow through challenging situations and how those responses differ within a program and outside a program. We are doing this to identify better the factors that lead to post-traumatic growth (PTG is defined below) and then to include these factors more deeply in our programming.
This report describes a recently identified buffering effect for participants within the ACSI program on the measure of Character Strengths overall and a more substantial buffering effect on Well-being and Life Satisfaction factors.

Post-Traumatic Stress vs Post-Traumatic Growth
Trauma and the accompanying stressors that persist do impact many people who go through an acute traumatic event, such as the blast that went off in Beirut last year, or sustained challenges, such as those emerging from the pandemic, economic collapse, and others. Individuals may have trouble concentrating, flashbacks, sensitivity to similar situations, and other negative experiences that develop after a traumatic event are called Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The research shows that after a traumatic event, there are three primary responses:
A small percentage of people who experience it develop PTSD,
The majority of people show resilience and return to the pre-event state,
Another minority demonstrates something called Post Traumatic Growth.

(Jeon 2015)
In Post-Traumatic Growth (PTG), after a traumatic event spent grappling with the challenges, there is a period of growth whereby people develop new strengths, see new possibilities, grow spiritually, develop closer relationships, and have a deeper appreciation for life.
These days, more programs are becoming trauma-informed and adapting accordingly, but there is little inclusion in entrepreneurship programs and little research focusing on how entrepreneurship programs can better support communities during and after traumatic events and post-traumatic growth. In an age of disruption and “new normals,” understanding what supports PTG is critical.
Evidence from the ACSI Program
To explore this further in the context of our programs, we have recently analyzed the Character Strengths profiles of people who went through our ACSI Sprint+Accelerator program versus those who just went through the ACSI Sprint Program.
For this cohort of participants, we have primary quantitative data collected at the beginning of the Sprint period (April 2020). We then selected a subset of teams for the longer 4-month Accelerator program, which we extended to six months due to the challenges in Lebanon and beyond.
It is important to note that these are small-scale studies with 13 participants within our accelerator program and 17 participants within the Sprint-only program.
Quantitative Evidence
We conducted the same quantitative assessment from December 2020 to January 2021, with the initial results shared here.
From an aggregated view, the ACSI program seemed to prevent a drop in overall character strengths. We collected samples of the ACSI Sprinters' character strengths profile at the beginning of the program during the sprint period. We re-assessed people who participated only in the Sprint and participants who completed the ACSI Accelerator program.
By comparing the pre/post changes across all 24 Character Strengths, we see that the ACSI teams that were part of the Accelerator program had a slight .2 point increase in their aggregated scores compared to the teams not part of the Accelerator program, which experienced a .6 point drop.
This exploration led to identifying that the impact of our program had a more substantial buffering effect on the facets that supported Life-Satisfaction and Well-being, mainly Humor, Zest, and Gratitude:
